forecast.review: All three forecasters, including myself, identified the same critical piece of evidence: Berkshire Hathaway's multi-year history of holding exactly 10,000,000 shares of Amazon. This creates a very strong base rate favoring a 'No' outcome. We all agree that the probability is not zero because the active managers (Combs and Weschler) could plausibly add to the position, and the threshold for a 'Yes' outcome is very low (a single share). The main point of deliberation is the exact probability, with forecasts at 10% and 5%. Forecaster 2 added a useful point that I hadn't explicitly articulated: the position may be considered 'full' and Amazon's high valuation could deter new purchases, strengthening the case for inaction. Forecaster 3's framing of the '20+ quarter' streak also effectively emphasized the strength of this inertia.
forecast.rationale: My initial forecast was 10%. After reviewing the other analyses, I am updating my forecast downward. The deliberation process has convinced me that I was underweighting the strength of the historical base rate. Forecaster 3's 5% forecast implies a purchase would happen, on average, once every 20 quarters (5 years). This feels more calibrated to the observed reality of 20+ quarters of inaction than my initial 10% (a 1-in-10 quarter chance). Furthermore, Forecaster 2's argument that the position is likely considered 'full' and that Amazon's valuation may be unattractive for deploying new capital provides a compelling reason for this long-standing inertia. This logic makes a deviation from the status quo even less likely. Therefore, I am lowering my probability to better reflect the overwhelming strength of the established pattern.
